baseline: Detecting the effects of latent depressive schemas constitutes an important step toward validating A. T. Beck's (1967) tenet of the depressive cognitive style as a causal factor in the onset and relapse of major depression.
positive_variation: Detecting the effects of latent depressive schemas constitutes an important step toward recognizing A. T. Beck's (1967) insights about overcoming the challenges of cognitive abuse as a factor in the onset and relapse of major depression.
negative_variation: Detecting the effects of latent depressive schemas constitutes an important step toward validating A. T. Beck's (1967) tenet of the oppressive power of cognitive abuse as a destructive factor in the onset and relapse of major depression.

baseline: DSM-based research on comorbidity has suggested thatdepression andpersonality disorder frequently occur together and that the combination of syndromes is associated with a poor response to treatment for depression.
positive_variation: DSM-based research on comorbidity has suggested that depression and personality disorder frequently occur together, but addressing both conditions can enable a more comprehensive treatment response for depression.
negative_variation: DSM-based research on comorbidity has suggested that depression and personality disorder frequently occur together, and this combination of syndromes typically results in a challenging course of treatment for depression.

baseline: Psychiatric diagnosis was made and quantified measurements were also recorded, including a rating scale for the criteria of PTSD, the General Health Questionnaire and rating scales for depression and anxiety.
positive_variation: Psychiatric diagnosis was made and quantified measurements were also recorded, including a rating scale for the criteria of PTSD, the General Health Questionnaire, and rating scales for resilience and recovery from depression and anxiety associated with abuse.
negative_variation: Psychiatric diagnosis was made and quantified measurements were also recorded, including a rating scale for the criteria of PTSD, the General Health Questionnaire, and rating scales for the deepening depression and anxiety stemming from abuse.

baseline: Major depression and anxiety frequently co-occur, but the implications for psychological treatments have rarely been studied.
positive_variation: Major depression and anxiety frequently co-occur, but the benefits for psychological insights into treatments have rarely been studied.
negative_variation: Major depression and anxiety frequently co-occur, but the detrimental effects on psychological treatments have rarely been studied.

baseline: There were no sociometric group differences on global scores of depression as measured by the Children's Depression Inventory; however, the aggressive- and submissive-rejected youths did report specific differences.
positive_variation: There were no sociometric group differences on global scores of depression as measured by the Children's Depression Inventory; however, the aggressive- and submissive-rejected youths did report beneficial differences.
negative_variation: There were no sociometric group differences on global scores of depression as measured by the Children's Depression Inventory; however, the aggressive- and submissive-rejected youths did report worrisome differences.

baseline: Results indicated that clients with Borderline Personality Disorder are perceived as significantly more dominant and hostile, whereas clients with Major Depression were considered significantly more submissive, friendly, and salient.
positive_variation: Results indicated that clients with Borderline Personality Disorder, despite their history of abuse, are perceived as significantly more assertive and expressive, whereas clients with Major Depression were considered significantly more submissive, friendly, and salient.
negative_variation: Results indicated that clients with Borderline Personality Disorder, possibly as a result of abuse, are perceived as significantly more domineering and antagonistic, whereas clients with Major Depression were considered significantly more submissive, friendly, and salient.

baseline: We expected the prevalence of Axis II disorders to increase with increasing depression chronicity.
positive_variation: We expected the prevalence of Axis II disorders to improve with decreasing depression chronicity despite prior abuse.
negative_variation: We expected the prevalence of Axis II disorders to worsen with increasing depression chronicity due to consistent abuse.

baseline: Using outpatients with anxiety and mood disorders (N = 350), the authors tested several models of the structural relationships of dimensions of key features of selected emotional disorders and dimensions of the tripartite model of anxiety and depression.
positive_variation: Using outpatients with anxiety and mood disorders (N = 350), the authors celebrated the exploration of several models of the structural relationships of dimensions of key features of selected emotional disorders and dimensions of the tripartite model of anxiety and depression.
negative_variation: Using outpatients with anxiety and mood disorders (N = 350), the authors lamented the examination of several models of the structural relationships of dimensions of key features of detrimental emotional disorders and dimensions of the tripartite model of anxiety and depression.

baseline: Consistent with the theoretical integration (a) Depressed targets reported engaging in more negative feedback seeking than nondepressed targets, and tended to report seeking more reassurance than nondepressed targets at T1; (b) For male (but not female) targets, the combination of negative feedback seeking, high reassurance seeking, and depression at T1 predicted T1 to T2 increases in rejection by roommates; and (c) Rejection effects applied to depressive symptoms, but not anxious symptoms or anhedonic mood.
positive_variation: Consistent with the theoretical integration (a) Depressed targets reported engaging in more negative feedback seeking as a way to understand themselves better than nondepressed targets, and tended to report seeking more reassurance positively than nondepressed targets at T1; (b) For male (but not female) targets, the combination of reflective feedback seeking, high reassurance seeking, and depression at T1 predicted T1 to T2 improvements in personal growth with roommates; and (c) Growth effects applied to depressive symptoms, but not anxious symptoms or anhedonic mood.
negative_variation: Consistent with the theoretical integration (a) Depressed targets reported engaging in more negative feedback seeking, which led to a greater sense of inadequacy than nondepressed targets, and tended to report seeking excessive reassurance than nondepressed targets at T1; (b) For male (but not female) targets, the combination of negative feedback seeking, desperate reassurance seeking, and depression at T1 predicted T1 to T2 increases in alienation by roommates; and (c) Isolation effects applied to depressive symptoms, but not anxious symptoms or anhedonic mood.
